clusters.title: Man charged with murder of woman after body found in Brisbane River
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Charged with Murder After Woman's Body Found in River

items.title: Man charged with murder of woman after body found in Brisbane River
items.standfirst: Police have charged a man on the Gold Coast seven months after a woman’s body was found.
items.content: Police have charged a man on the Gold Coast seven months after a woman’s body was found.

items.title: Man charged with murder after mother's body found in river following family dinner
items.standfirst: C rystal Beale, 49, had left a family dinner one night in February and took a ride with her her killer, police now allege.
items.content: A man has been charged with murder over the death of mother-of-two Crystal Beale, whose body was found in a river earlier this year in Brisbane.Police combed through 1000 hours of CCTV footage in a "complex and protracted" seven-month investigation after Beale, 49, was found dead on Saturday, February 22. A member of the public saw Beale's body in the Brisbane River about 5.40am and contacted police.READ MORE: Staggering number of Aussie jobs at risk over AIREAD MORE: MAGA firebrand laughs on stage at Charlie Kirk memorialInvestigators believe that at 8.30pm on Friday, February 1, Beale left a family dinner at a Sunnybank restaurant and travelled with a 49-year-old West End man, who was known to her.He was allegedly the last person to see Beale alive when she got out of the car at 9.30pm on Ryan Street, West End.But police now allege the man killed Beale and put her body into the Brisbane River. Police searched an Equestrian Drive address in Maudsland at 5.11am today.A 49-year-old man was arrested and charged with domestic violence murder and misconduct with a corpse.Detective Inspector Wayne Francis could not confirm the nature of Beale's relationship with the man but said police will allege there was a history of domestic violence. Francis said Beale's children were doing "as best they can" given the circumstances."They've lost their mother through horrible circumstances, no matter what court action occurs subsequently, they can't get their mother back," he said.Police are still keen for anyone with information to still come forward.Francis said a White Ford Ranger was identified as a car of interest during the investigation. "I would just like to thank the investigators involved for their dedication and professionalism," he added. The charged man is expected to appear in court today. Support is available from the National Sexual Assault, Domestic and Family Violence Counselling Service at 1800RESPECT (1800 737 732).

ai_summary: A man has been charged with murder on the Gold Coast.
The charges relate to the death of a woman whose body was found in a river.
The body of Crystal Beale, 49, was found in the Brisbane River.
Police allege the accused killer gave Beale a ride after a family dinner.
The man was charged seven months after the woman's body was found.

items.title: Childcare worker charged with assaulting boy, 4
items.standfirst: Police began investigating after receiving a report of a four-year-old being assaulted at a centre on Day Street in Bathurst on August 29.
items.content: A childcare worker has been charged with assaulting a child at a daycare centre in NSW's central west.Police began investigating after receiving a report of a four-year-old being assaulted at a centre on George Street in Bathurst on August 29.It is alleged the 18-year-old female staff member grabbed the child by the arm and dragged him across the room, before grabbing him a second time and throwing him onto a mattress.READ MORE: MAGA firebrand laughs on stage at Charlie Kirk memorialREAD MORE: Australia in firing line as Israeli leader blasts global superpowersThe child's shirt was ripped near the armpit during the incident, police said.The 18-year-old woman was issued with a court attendance notice for common assault today.She is no longer employed at the daycare centre, according to police.The charged woman will front Bathurst Local Court on November 17. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Four things to watch for at the UN's biggest meeting of the year
items.standfirst: World leaders are arriving in New York for the UN General Assembly — and for the first time, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is among them.
items.content: World leaders are arriving in New York for the UN General Assembly — and for the first time, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is among them.

ai_summary: World leaders are arriving in New York for the UN General Assembly.
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is attending for the first time.
The UN General Assembly is the biggest meeting of the year.
The meeting will address global issues.
The event is a significant gathering of international leaders.

clusters.title: Groomed at 15, married at 21. How Sarah finally exposed her predatory teacher
clusters.neutral_headline: Woman exposes predatory teacher after grooming and marriage

items.title: Groomed at 15, married at 21. How Sarah finally exposed her predatory teacher
items.standfirst: Sarah Kopp's life was up-ended when a charismatic teacher twice her age started grooming her. Then they married and had children. When she sought justice 20 years on, she faced an impossible choice.
items.content: Sarah Kopp's life was up-ended when a charismatic teacher twice her age started grooming her. Then they married and had children. When she sought justice 20 years on, she faced an impossible choice.

ai_summary: Sarah Kopp was groomed by a teacher twice her age at fifteen.
They later married and had children together.
She sought justice twenty years later.
She faced a difficult choice in seeking justice.
The teacher's actions upended her life.

clusters.title: Older Australians to pay up to $50/hour for personal care like showers
clusters.neutral_headline: Older Australians to pay for personal care services

items.title: Older Australians to pay up to $50/hour for personal care like showers
items.standfirst: Older Australians entering the aged care system will have to pay for "non-clinical" services such as showers and help with medication under wide-ranging changes taking effect in November.
items.content: Older Australians entering the aged care system will have to pay for "non-clinical" services such as showers and help with medication under wide-ranging changes taking effect in November.

ai_summary: Older Australians will pay for non-clinical services.
Services include showers and help with medication.
Changes will take effect in the aged care system in November.
The changes will impact the cost of care.
The changes are wide-ranging.

clusters.title: AI is 'coming at us fast'. But what exactly is it being used for right now?
clusters.neutral_headline: AI industry growth and concerns in Australia

items.title: AI is 'coming at us fast'. But what exactly is it being used for right now?
items.standfirst: It's estimated 30,000 people are working in the AI industry in Australia, and fanfare is growing with start-ups tapping into billions of dollars of venture capital. Yet there are concerns about hype and a lack of regulation.
items.content: It's estimated 30,000 people are working in the AI industry in Australia, and fanfare is growing with start-ups tapping into billions of dollars of venture capital. Yet there are concerns about hype and a lack of regulation.

ai_summary: An estimated 30,000 people work in the AI industry in Australia.
Start-ups are tapping into billions of dollars of venture capital.
There are concerns about hype and a lack of regulation.
The AI industry is experiencing rapid growth.
The industry is facing challenges related to regulation.
